description: Marv Thornsberry So Deanna's been having a hard time with this pain that radiates in her arm every night.  The surgery didn't work and it's getting to her.  I've been working a lot too since January with my new position. So yesterday I suggested we take the day off today and do whatever she wanted to do.  So we did!  We went out to lunch after a leisurely morning.  After lunch to my surprise she took me took me to this place I had not been before.  It was a massage parlor of sorts!  We walked in and all the therapists were Asian!  I started wondering who this day was for!  She knows I have a thing for Asians! (What male doesn't).   So she picks out an Asian guy for her and an Asian girl for me!  (Those of you who remember the co-worker nurse of hers that she brought to my 40th birthday party know Dea knows how to pick them for me)!   Anyway the massage starts along with the rub down and lotions!  But I guess because my wife was there, the chic would not rub any lotion above my knees!  Then she proceeded to give me a pedi!  Then I realized it wasn't one of the Asian parlors I was used too!  So today I had my first pedi ever and I had to because I promised I would do whatever Dea wanted to do today!  It was good to hear her laugh, it had been awhile! Robin Reese Heppner

description: Marv Thornsberry The kids in this video including the musicians are given 4 days to learn their dance routines, lyrics, and music.  This performance is the first time the musicians actually play the music together.  The event is sponsored every year by the Indiana 4-H program in partnership with Purdue's Music Program.  The show choir group is made up of students picked from all over the state and they all meet for the first time at Purdue where they spend 4 days learning the song and dance routines for 12 - 15 songs.  Having helped Connor and the choir band during New Pal's Show Choir competition season last year, I know what an amazing feat these kids are able to pull off in 4 days!  It is not competition level (which is only 4-5 routines practiced for several months), but amazing and entertaining none the less.  They perform just short of an  hour and this is just one of the routines.

description: So this is a pic of Connor this morning as he and I went to breakfast before school on this his last day!  Many mornings when the boys were in 1st thru 5th grade, I would take them to school.  Some days we would leave early enough to go to breakfast together at Cafe 52.  When Connor started 4th grade it was the first year he was going to school that his brothers were not there with him, they had b ... oth moved to middle school by then.  His first day he was nervous about it, so he and I went to breakfast at Cafe 52 (his brothers now started too early to go with us anymore).  While waiting for the food I decided to make a paper football and we played the game.  He got so into trying to beat me that he forgot about his brothers not being there.  For the next 2 years this became our thing a couple of days a week until he went to middle school and once in awhile after that on late start days until Cafe 52 closed a couple of years ago.  This morning we went and played one last game at Seros, which is normally too far out of the way, but he didn't need to be at school until 10:30 for graduation practice which is tomorrow evening.  I kept the game ball so he could autograph it!  He beat me 17 to 16.  The game was always over when the food showed up!  Good luck at IU Connor!   See More

description: Marv Thornsberry  updated their status. The day after the last day, The First Day!  Twenty Four and a half years ago my friend Melanie set me up on a blind date with a classmate of her's in nursing school at U of I.  On March 20th 1992,  I knocked on her door, it was already dark that evening and in the moonlight it was hard to see when she opened the door!  Then she smiled and her braces glistened!  She must have seen the surprised look on my face because she said "Oh hi you must be Marv, here for my sister Deanna, I am Mandy! (Relieved!)  Then Dea appeared in the doorway with that doll face of hers!   Mandy is her little sister who she was raising since their Mom had passed away from cancer 2 years before when Mandy was 13.  From that first moment I realized if this was going anywhere, it was to be a packaged deal!  Three years later Mandy was 18 and still living with us when Hunter was born.  Shortly after, Mandy graduated from Lawrence Central and went off to college at ISU.  Then Tanner was born and Connor.  In the boys childhood years, for a short time we also raised Deanna's nephew, from another sister, who was single and needed help (she has since passed away too from cancer).  Her son Robbie was failing in middle school and he himself reached out to us for help.  With his Mom's approval, we took him in and raised him through his high school years.  During this time he became like a big brother to our boys, they are still tight today!  Robbie graduated from New Palestine High School with academic honors and attended USI for awhile.  He quit after awhile, deciding he wanted to help his grandfather build homes.  He is married now and has 2 little girls of his own.  Also during our sons growing years my little brother David passed away and his son Chase who was 5 at the time (one year older than Connor) then spent most of his summers with us for the next 11 years.  (Mostly he grew up with his Mom in Jasper, Indiana and he is now a sophomore at Western Kentucky).  Then comes this past weekend and you all know how bittersweet it was as we moved Hunter back to Purdue Saturday,  Tanner back to IU and Connor to IU for his Freshman year yesterday!  I have loved every minute of the past 24 and a half years and would not trade a single moment of it for anything in the world, but TODAY is the First Day  I don't have to share Dea with anyone (unless you count the dog and when the boys are home for breaks and summers until they graduate)!  I am so looking forward to having OUR time now and growing old(er) with her!  P.S.  I hope she likes me and we are broke right now too!  LOL

description: Marv Thornsberry  updated their status. The 3rd and final Last Night!  Three years ago Hunter went off to college and that last night under our care was the hardest night I ever had to let go of. Knowing that now he was going to be the one totally responsible for his own future success was exciting because we knew deep down he was ready and anxious to go do it.  But knowing it was also his responsibility to keep himself safe was the hardest part of my job as a parent to let go of.  Being able to send a text and get an immediate response helps, but you soon realize it is a false sense of security.  But letting go was a little easier because there was Tanner and Connor still depending on us and needing us (although not much  :-)  ).  Then two years ago we go through it all over again with Tanner going off to college and choosing a different one than Hunter.  You think it might be a little easier this time, but it's not!  Again deep down we know he is ready and anxious to do it too!  But all the same emotions, thoughts, and concern for his safety and now both of them, rises up and grabs me again.  But letting go was a little easier because there was Connor still depending on us and needing us (although again not much  :-)  ).   Then comes last night, the final one and Connor leaves today and there are those damn emotions, thoughts, and concern for his safety and now all three of them, rising up and grabbing me again.  We know deep down, just like the first two, he is ready and anxious to do it too!  But damn, it is still not any easier!  He is the last, so the little comfort that comes this time is found in knowing Hunter is a Senior and Tanner a Junior, and they have done us proud so far and have learned how to keep themselves safe.  I know from my own experience and them that this is the most exciting, challenging, yet fun time in all three of their lives and we will turn to continue watching it from a distance and enjoy it, just not today.  To all those parents who have done this already and told us about this empty nest syndrome,  Thanks, but it didn't help!

description: Marv Thornsberry As all of you know I lost my Dad on the first day of this month, in dealing with everything this is the first day I am feeling he is gone.  But I have learned something that I hope he is seeing too!  My brother's and sister's know that a huge part of Dad's last few years he spent worrying about all of us, his grandchildren, great grand children, their friends, and all of the young people in the world with all of the evil that surrounds us and them and is undoubtedly more of in their future.  But with all of the outpouring of support, the long line at the funeral, the cards, the messages, the phone calls, the Likes, I now realize how much good is in our world.  This same good surrounds the families of every funeral I have attended in my life and there are more of them as I age too.  I also know first hand from being an IT person, as a part of my job supporting the Marion County Sheriff's Department and The Indianapolis Police Department, that it is a very small percentage of the world doing most of the crimes in the world.  It is just that all of us good people in the world have become more tolerant and passive.  But some day the evil will push all the good young people (that my Dad worried about) too far and they will rise up and wipe the evil from this earth and no one had best try to stand in their way.  I might feel sorry for the religious extremists or countries that incur their wrath when it comes, but probably not.  All of you have shown me how much good truly surrounds us!  Happy Father's Day to my Dad and all the Dad's like him who helped keep the good strong!

description: Marv Thornsberry  was with  Chase Thornsberry  and  8 others . As I reach this milestone today I look back at how fortunate I have been in my life so far.  I've always done things a little differently and God knows I haven't been perfect but I've tried.  I have awesome parents and my Mom is still going strong!  I also have 5 older siblings and I've been following their lead and footsteps!  They of course had kids before I did and they taught me the right way to raise children.  They all have kids that are great adults with kids of their own now.  With Dea's help I have raised my own now too and helped with 4 others!  Our boys have already made me proud with who they are and how they are progressing through college.  My career is finally in full swing and in high gear and I work for a great company!   As I start the next phase of my life, going through this 40's mid-life crisis thing I've heard about,  I will once again try to learn from my older siblings experiences.  But I have planned well for it.  I married a much younger girl who is still smoking hot (as the Bristol NASCAR preacher would say about his wife and like him I thank God for her everyday) .  So some more new lingerie should do the trick just fine!   Once I get through this phase I will once again watch and learn how my older siblings are handling their grand-parenting.  Then God willing, Dea and I will begin preparing for those years in the near future!  I am looking forward to the next hopefully 40+ years of my life!  😎 Marv Thornsberry

description: *** UPDATE ON THIS POST ***   Tanner received his results from the MCAT entrance exam to med school today, which he took a month ago.  He out scored 80% of all test takers world wide who took the test this time!  Tanner said "This is one of the happiest days of my life ever!"  Now we sit back and see what the med schools he applied to have to say about this!  Way to go Tanner, we are proud, but not ...  surprised! ****    Our son Tanner (on the left) is taking the MCAT test tomorrow hoping to gain entrance into medical school. He has been preparing for it his whole life and has been focused on it since before middle school! Since he set upon his dream no kid has ever studied, worked harder, or stayed more focused than he has! He wants to walk in his mother's footsteps and beyond! His big day is finally here and it's an 8 hour long test! Along with his preparedness, we wish him all the luck in the world and a little help from God! Deanna and I hope this is Tanner's calling, the health care field would truly benefit from the person he has become! (They were operating on Connor's Lamby as he was in bad shape since Connor carried him everywhere he went to this point in his life!
